title: Sony Rejects Third Point’s Proposal Calling for a Company Breakup
text:
Sony Corp. SNE -0.65% said it rejected a proposal from activist hedge fund Third Point LLC to split its image-sensor business from its entertainment business and list the chip unit.

On Tuesday, Sony said its image-sensor business is a “crucial growth driver” that “is expected to create even more value going forward through its close collaboration with the other businesses and personnel” at the company.

Sony said the image-sensor business will continue to focus on imaging applications but will also keep growing in developing markets like the Internet of Things and autonomous driving. In June, Third Point, which is run by Daniel Loeb, said Sony’s stock is undervalued and its portfolio is too complicated. It said it spent $1.5 billion in building up its position in Sony. Satoshi Yoshihara, senior general manager of mobile and sensing systems business division at Sony Semiconductor Solutions, with a wafer of 3D sensors last December. Photo: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg News Third Point also said Sony should look at selling stakes in a number of companies, including Olympus Corp. OCPNY -0.23% and Spotify Technology SA SPOT -1.88% . Late last month, Sony said it would sell its whole 5% stake in Olympus—valued at more than 80 billion yen ($740 million)—as it reviewed its other shareholdings. In 2013, Mr. Loeb tried to rally Sony shareholders to support a spinoff of the company’s movie and music assets. Sony rejected his proposal and Third Point sold its Sony stake in 2014.
